subtasks: Timing land preparation (ploughing, harrowing) according to soil moisture and rainfall patterns.
Determining optimal planting dates (showing) considering historical rainfall data and pest/disease cycles.
Monitoring soil moisture levels to predict leaf miner and other pest outbreaks.
Applying pesticides when triggered by specific weather conditions (e.g., lack of rainfall followed by drought).
Using drenching showers (intense rainfall) to mitigate pest populations.
Managing late leaf spot (Tikka) and other diseases through timely monitoring of rainfall patterns.
Using three consecutive days of very wet soil conditions to predict disease onset.
Hand-weeding or managing weeds during specific critical periods (35–80 days after sowing) based on soil moisture triggers.
Evaluating peanut grow model outputs to compare with district yield data.
Adjusting offtake (reducing yield expectations) based on predicted pest and disease losses.
Assessing the probability of pest infestations (e.g., leaf miner, late leaf spot) using climatological data.
Weighing the cost of pesticides against potential yield losses to determine optimal spraying strategies.
Considering the skill and reliability of weather forecasts (probabilities of wet or dry spells) in informing pesticide application decisions.
Adapting management practices (e.g., showing dates, varieties) to match the local rainfall variability (climate tailoring).
